perturbation.original_text: 8.1 ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS. VerticalNet and Neoforma shall use commercially reasonable efforts to co-promote the VerticalNet Medical Online Communities, the Co-Branded Sites, the VerticalNet Buyer's Guide, Neoforma Plan, Neoforma Shop and Neoforma Auction in mutually agreeable advertising, collateral marketing material and sales force activities. All co-promotion advertising materials produced by or on behalf of either Party (the "Originating Party") shall be subject to the written approval of the other Party (the "Receiving Party"), which approval shall not to be unreasonably withheld, delayed or conditioned. The Receiving Party shall notify the Originating Party of its approval or disapproval of such advertising materials as soon as practicable, but in any event within five business days after Receiving Party's receipt thereof. Any failure of the Receiving Party to respond within such five business day period shall be deemed disapproval of the advertising materials in question.
perturbation.changed_text: 8.1 ADVERTISING CAMPAIGNS. VerticalNet and Neoforma shall use commercially reasonable efforts to co-promote the VerticalNet Medical Online Communities, the Co-Branded Sites, the VerticalNet Buyer's Guide, Neoforma Plan, Neoforma Shop and Neoforma Auction in mutually agreeable advertising, collateral marketing material and sales force activities. All co-promotion advertising materials produced by or on behalf of either Party (the "Originating Party") shall be subject to the written approval of the other Party (the "Receiving Party"), which approval shall not to be unreasonably withheld, delayed or conditioned. The Receiving Party shall notify the Originating Party of its approval or disapproval of such advertising materials within one business day after Receiving Party's receipt thereof. Any failure of the Receiving Party to respond within such one business day period shall be deemed approval of the advertising materials in question.
perturbation.explanation: The original text provides a five-business-day period for approval or disapproval of advertising materials. Reducing this period to one business day places an unreasonable burden on the Receiving Party to review and respond to the materials, potentially leading to rushed or overlooked evaluations. This creates a conflict with standard business practices that mandate a reasonable time frame for review and approval processes, making the quick turnaround of only one day a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General contract law principles requiring reasonableness in contractual terms

perturbation.original_text: 11.1 AUTOMATIC RENEWAL. This Agreement will automatically renew at the end of the Initial Term or a subsequent renewal term on a year to year basis (each, a "Renewal Term"), unless either Party notifies the other at least 30 days prior to the end of the Initial Term or then current Renewal Term, as applicable, of its intention not to renew this Agreement (a "Termination Notice").
perturbation.changed_text: 11.1 AUTOMATIC RENEWAL. This Agreement will automatically renew at the end of the Initial Term or a subsequent renewal term on a year to year basis (each, a "Renewal Term"), unless either Party notifies the other at least 10 days prior to the end of the Initial Term or then current Renewal Term, as applicable, of its intention not to renew this Agreement (a "Termination Notice").
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for non-renewal from 30 days to 10 days may conflict with state laws that require reasonable notice periods for contract termination, especially in agreements of this complexity. This short notice could be deemed insufficient time for the other party to adequately prepare for the termination of the agreement and secure alternative arrangements. By shortening the time, it creates a contradiction with state regulations on adequate notice periods for contract renewals.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State laws governing reasonable notice periods for contract termination and renewal.

perturbation.original_text: 12.5 TWO YEAR LIMITATION. Except for claims under Sections 15.4  [INDEMNIFICATION BY NEOFORMA] and 15.5  [INDEMNIFICATION BY VERTICALNET] hereof, neither Party may bring a claim or action regardless of form, arising out of or related to this Agreement, including any claim of fraud or misrepresentation, more than two years after the cause of action accrues or becomes known, whichever is later.
perturbation.changed_text: 12.5 ONE YEAR LIMITATION. Except for claims under Sections 15.4  [INDEMNIFICATION BY NEOFORMA] and 15.5  [INDEMNIFICATION BY VERTICALNET] hereof, neither Party may bring a claim or action regardless of form, arising out of or related to this Agreement, including any claim of fraud or misrepresentation, more than one year after the cause of action accrues or becomes known, whichever is later.
perturbation.explanation: The original text sets a two-year limitation for claims arising from the agreement. By reducing this to one year, it may contradict statutes of limitations in certain states for contract disputes, particularly for claims of fraud or misrepresentation which often have longer statutory periods. This abbreviated limitation could make it difficult for parties to pursue legitimate claims if the full extent of damages or wrongdoing is not discovered within the shortened one-year window.
perturbation.contradicted_law: State statutes of limitations for contract disputes and fraud claims.
